content.description: Start this awesome, evil crimpfest on Don't Call Me Dude. Where DCMD heads up and left, continue right and up for another 50feet. You gotta have steel fingers for this one. Burley for 14a.
content.location: start one route left of Necessary evil. Go up then right into necessary evil.

content.description: 100 percent natural. This was the original concept line bolted by Boone Speed. In order to climb the majority of it, he started on Don't Call Me Dude. With Boone Speed's blessing, Chris Sharma linked the original start of Necessary Evil to Route of All Evil. Sharma describes this as a 5.14a boulder route, with another 5.14a stacked on top of it, broken up only by a bad shake out hold.
content.location: Starts just left of the two large rocks

climbs.name: I Saw Jesus at the Chains

content.description: Goes up the overhang on far left of Blasphemy Wall, then a sustained face to a run out slab.

High Flames Drifter is the bottom half of Bogus Pedophile Charges 12c. 

  Climb some large yet challenging pockets to a roof and do a couple of insecure crimp moves to a horizontal break.  After resting, some large pockets lead to another rest, then power past the crux bulge to an insecure slab finish.  

  This route would be classic at almost any other crag.
content.protection: Bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.  Keep going for Bogus Pedophile Charges.
content.location: On the left side of the wall between Fall of Man and I Saw Jesus at the Chains.

content.description:
Previously excluded from the Mountain Project because I couldn't give it sixty million stars, but accurately described on rockclimbing.com: "Fall of Man, 5.13b.  This route gets progressively harder until you take a long whipper at the top." 

  I remember reading somewhere that Fall of Man was the first "futuristic" line in the VRG.  It is a world-class stretch of perfect limestone... a breathtaking and outrageously intimidating line up the very center of the Blasphemy Wall. 

  Climb up the steep A-shaped recess on hand jams and pockets to an intermediate anchor (this is Fall of Mouse - maybe a 5.11 something?), don't stop, and instead perform a powerful move to an angling hold... this can be a body tension reach or deadpoint, but either way it's a dramatic entry onto the upper wall.  Follow vertical slots and pockets up 50' of gently overhanging climbing past many difficult moves and hard earned clips, resting at a ledge or higher at a hueco just as the angle eases to vertical.  Say goodbye to your belayer, grab the credit card, and launch up into the slab crux!!!  Several clips worth of terror, jake brakes, and beautifully sculpted pockets and edges culminate with a final 20' runout to the chains.
content.protection: Fixed draws. Be prepared to whip.  A very stretchy 70m is required to lower off the chains, but it is probably better to work the route from the last two bolts.

content.description: A link up of the cruxes of Dude, Dark Boy, and Fall Of Man. It ranks with one of the most awesome routes in the US. If F-Dude were its own, independent line, it would be even better. It climb with a graceful and pumpy flow that is world class.
content.location: At the big horizontal jug of Dude, move left to Dark Boy. Take that route for another few bolts until another F-Dude bolt allows you to link up with Fall of Man.

content.description: This route starts on Bloody Mary and moves right after the 5th bolt; there is a slight down step to the right to some jugs and then back up through the line of fixed draws. This is a power endurance route with few obvious rests for a while. Some holds seem to have broken at some point, but it is still climbable. Beautiful line on stellar rock.
content.location: Right side of Blasphemy Wall. Start on Bloody Mary then cut right at 5th bolt.

content.description: Dude is a stout 13c, and possibly a letter grade harder if you are under 5'8" tall. This is a real classic VRG testpiece and mixes up a lot of different types of moves. Start as for F-Dude than branch out right.
content.location: Start two routes left of Necessary Evil

content.description: super stellar climbing broken up into three sections.. the first being about 11b, second being the 13b section, and the last being the prize winning 12a that you are rewarded after climbing through the crux... If the last section were its own route it would be the best warm up at the gorge.. this route is awesome and kinda sporty!!

This is probably the easiest climb at the Blasphemy Wall but because of a crimpy opening sequence makes for an average warmup.  Begin by scrambling up the 20' high boulder that sits against the far right side of the wall.  Reach across and make a clip, then step over to the wall and climb through the crux and another clip.  A few bolts higher, traverse left to easier climbing (straight up is 5.13).
Climb High Flames and keep going up through edges and slab climbing to a couple good rests intermixed. Sparse bolts keep it engaging.
content.location: Start on High Flames Drifter and continue straight up past the two bolt anchor. In between I saw Jesus at the Chains and Fall of Man.

content.description: This is the extension to Bloody Mary.  Clip the chains and continue rock routing for several more safety clips (stay left at the intersection a few bolts after the chains).  Use small and medium hand holds and good, high textured foot holds to advance yourself to the top of the wall.  An 80 meter safety line is advised, but a 70 meter safety line could potentially work if you lower to the top of the boulder or sport rappel twice.*It is most courteous to not try this at the start of the day when everyone is using Bloody Mary as the warm up
content.protection: Safety clipsBloody Mary is perma-draws, the extension had nylon draws on it as of 1/2021, but they were looking a bit worse for the wear.
content.location: Start on Bloody Mary and keep going up.

content.description: This wall is furthest left on the shady side.  It is a tall and steep striped wall that is home to a host of classic 5.13's as well as Chris Sharma's Necessary Evil (5.14c).
